pork.Name: Caramelized Oven-Baked Pork Ham
pork.Instructions:
I started by preparing the ham for boiling. Yes, it needs to boil for a while. I tied the ham tightly (with some help from my husband), just like in the picture. Then, in a pressure cooker, I placed the rolled ham, enough water to cover it, peeled and sliced the carrots, and quartered the onion. I also added the crushed pepper, coriander seeds, cinnamon sticks, and bay leaves. I let everything simmer for about an hour and a half.

The next step was to remove the skin, score the ham, and insert cloves here and there.

To prepare the caramel sauce, I preheated the oven to 170°C and started the brown sugar sauce. Here's what I did: in a small pot, I placed all the ingredients and let them cook over medium heat until the sugar melted, and the sauce foamed. The entire process took about 5 minutes. Stir occasionally but keep an eye on it, as it can easily overflow. Once the sauce was ready, I coated the ham with this wonderful sauce and placed it in the oven.

After 15 minutes, I took it out, coated it with half of the caramel sauce, and returned it to the oven for another 35 minutes.

It was done when the surface became golden and slightly crispy. After removing it from the oven, I let it rest for 15 minutes before slicing. The taste is divine, balanced with cinnamon and cloves, subtle but not overpowering. It pairs wonderfully with a good glass of red wine.

pork.Name: Oven-Baked Pork Belly in Dark Beer
pork.Instructions:
Pork loves beer, especially if the meat has been salted and chilled overnight. The salt dehydrates and tenderizes the meat, preparing it for the feast to come.

I cleaned off the excess salt from the pork belly and placed it in a large pot over chopped vegetables. I poured the dark beer over everything. The 600 ml should cover the vegetables but not the meat. I added bay leaves and peppercorns, covered the pot (very important, or the beer will evaporate and the meat will dry out), and cooked it in the oven at 150°C for 4.5 hours.

Once cooked, I transferred it to a grill on a baking tray, raised the temperature to 220°C, and let it cook for 10-15 minutes to get a golden crust.

Meanwhile, I prepared the dark beer sauce by straining the liquid from the pot, simmering it, and reducing it by half. I blended the cooked vegetables into the sauce, and after 15 minutes, the sauce was ready. I garnished the pork belly with thyme and served it with crispy potatoes and green beans.

pork.Name: Pork Chop with Butter Sauce
pork.Instructions:
First, I scored the thin layer of fat without cutting into the meat to prevent juice loss and keep the meat tender in the oven.

How did I do the dry marinade?
I seasoned the chop with salt, paprika, lemon pepper, garlic, onion, and thyme, and left it in the fridge for 48 hours to absorb the flavors.

How did I do the wet marinade?
After 48 hours, I continued with a wet marinade for another 2-3 hours using olive oil and Herbs de Provence, along with coconut oil.

Cooking preparation:
I placed the marinated chop on a grill in the oven at 170°C for about 3 hours, basting it occasionally with juices from the pan. After 2 hours, I moved the chop to another tray without water and let it brown for another hour.

At the end, I brushed the meat with a butter sauce made with dill, parsley, and thyme.

pork.Name: Slow-Cooked Pork
pork.Instructions:
I started by marinating the meat with salt, pepper, and paprika, then seasoned it with onion, garlic, lovage, and rosemary, and left it in the fridge for 2 hours.

After the time passed, I seared the meat for 2 minutes on each side in a pan. I placed it in a deep baking dish over the root vegetables, the marinade ingredients, wine, and water, covered it well with foil, and baked it at 160°C for 5 hours.

The result was incredibly tender meat that melts in your mouth.

For the mashed potatoes, I boiled the red potatoes, mashed them, added cream and cold butter for creaminess.

For the mushrooms, I sautéed them with garlic, added rosé wine, and finished with butter.

I also grilled some roasted pumpkin for serving.
